case_name: War Profits Tax Commissioner v. M/s Binodram Balchand

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1965 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 6, 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 108 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated September 6, 1962 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 108 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 6, 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 108 of 1958.

facts.text: Reference made to High Court under s. 46 of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance, Samvat 2001.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh in a reference made to it under s. 46 of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance, Samvat 2001-hereinafter called the Ordinance.

facts.text: Question No. 1 referred: Whether the dividend income of Rs. 11,09,332 received from the Binod Mills was chargeable under the War Profits Tax?

anchor.surface_text: Three questions were referred to the High Court by the War Profits Tax Commissioner, but we are only concerned with question No. 1, which reads as follows - Whether the dividend income of Rs. 11,09,332/received from the Binod Mills was chargeable under the War Profits Tax?

facts.text: Assessees are M/s Binodram Balchand of Ujjain.

anchor.surface_text: When the reference was first heard by the High Court three contentions were raised by M/s Binodram Balchand of Ujjain, respondents before us, hereinafter referred to as the assessees.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated April 19, 1957 accepted first contention of assessees.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment dated April 19, 1957, accepted the first contention of the assessees and accordingly answered the question in their favour. It did not deal with contentions Nos. 2 and 3.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment dated December 20, 1961 set aside High Court judgment and remanded for consideration of other contentions.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner appealed to this Court and this Court by its judgment dated December 20, 1961, set aside the judgment of the High Court and answered the first contention in relation to question No. I against the assessees and remanded the case to the High Court for the consideration of the other two contentions with reference to that question.

facts.text: High Court on remand accepted second contention of assessees and answered question No. 1 in their favour.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on remand accepted the second contention of the assessees and answered question No. 1, set out above, in favour of the assessees.

facts.text: Assessees were Managing Agents of Binod Mills Ltd., Ujjain at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees were, at the relevant time, the Managing Agents of the Binod Mills Ltd., Ujjain, which was a private limited company carrying on the business of manufacturing and selling textile goods in 1944.

facts.text: Binod Mills Ltd. was a private limited company carrying on business of manufacturing and selling textile goods in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees were, at the relevant time, the Managing Agents of the Binod Mills Ltd., Ujjain, which was a private limited company carrying on the business of manufacturing and selling textile goods in 1944.

facts.text: Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance, Samvat 2001 promulgated by Ruler of Gwalior State, came into force on July 1, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The Ruler of the Gwalior State promulgated the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance, Samvat 2001, for the purpose of imposing tax on excess profits arising out of certain businesses. The Ordinance came into force on July 1, 1944,

facts.text: Ordinance originally applied to accounting period July 1, 1944 to June 30, 1945, extended to June 30, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and applied originally to the accounting period falling within the period commencing on July 1, 1944, and ending on June 30, 1945. By virtue of a notification the period was extended to June 30, 1946.

facts.text: Assessees submitted return for period July 1, 1944 to October 16, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees carried on the Managing Agency business during the aforesaid period in Gwalior State and being liable to be assessed to war profits submitted a return for the period commencing from July 1, 1944, to October 16, 1944.

facts.text: Assessees received Rs. 11,09,332 on July 5, 1944 as dividend on shares of Binod Mills for the year 1943.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Rs. 11,09,332/- was received by the assessees on July 5, 1944, on account of dividend on shares of the Binod Mills for the year 1943.

facts.text: War Profits Tax Officer included Rs. 11,09,332 in taxable income by order dated July 9, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The War Profits Tax Officer, however, by order dated July 9, 1951, included this sum of Rs. 11,09,132/- in the taxable income and his view was upheld in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Commissioner.

facts.text: View of War Profits Tax Officer upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The War Profits Tax Officer, however, by order dated July 9, 1951, included this sum of Rs. 11,09,132/- in the taxable income and his view was upheld in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Commissioner.

facts.text: Assessees contended that their holdings in Binod Mills were purely investments with no connection to their business.

anchor.surface_text: They were The assessees did not deal in shares and their holdings in the Binod Mills Limited were purely in the nature of investments, having no connections with their business as defined in Section 25 read with Rule 1 of Schedule 1, of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance.

facts.text: Assessees contended dividend income excluded under explanation to Rule 3(1) of Schedule 1 as from profits of Binod Mills to which Ordinance applied.

anchor.surface_text: The dividend income accrued or arose from the profits of the Binod Mills Limited, and as the Ordinance applied to the business carried on by this company, the dividends were excluded under the explanation to Rule 3(1) of Schedule 1.

facts.text: Gwalior War Profits Tax Amendment Ordinance, Samvat 2002 promulgated on February 28, 1946 added Explanation to Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 2 of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Amendment Ordinance, Samvat 2002-hereinafter referred to as, Ordinance 2002, r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Ordinance was amended as follows - ... This Ordinance was promulgated on February 28, 1946.

facts.text: Gwalior War Profits Tax Amendment Ordinance, Samvat 2004 promulgated on September 6, 1947 made Explanation retrospective.

anchor.surface_text: Another Ordinance called the Gwalior War Profits Tax Amendment Ordinance, Samvat 2004-hereinafter referred to as Ordinance 2004-was promulgated on September 6, 1947.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Explanation applies to computation of profits for period July 1, 1944 to October 16, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: But even if it was added subsequently, in our opinion, the explanation applies to the computation of the profits of the chargeable accounting period July 1, 1944 to October 16, 1944.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that answer to question No. 1 is in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question referred should be in the negative.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 6, 1962 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 108 of 1958.
The Commissioner having obtained special leave, the appeal is now before us for disposal. A few facts may be given in order to appreciate the point that has.

This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh in a reference made to it under s. 46 of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance, Samvat 2001-hereinafter called the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed - The language of the explanation is very plain, and it means that if income is received by way of dividends or profits from a company carrying on a business, to the whole of which the section of the Ordinance imposing the War Profits Tax applies, then the income has to be excluded in the assessment to War Profits Tax of the assessee receiving that income. The object of the explanation is clearly to avoid double taxation.

concepts.interpretation: Purpose of Explanation to Rule 3 is to prevent taxing same profits as war profits tax at company level and again as dividend at assessee level

anchor.surface_text: But even if it was added subsequently, in our opinion, the explanation applies to the computation of the profits of the chargeable accounting period July 1, 1944 to October 16, 1944. arguments.claim: Explanation to Rule 3 applies to both sub-rules 3(1) and 3(2) as language is comprehensive and no distinction intended

anchor.surface_text: First, the words the income from investments to be included in the profits of the business under the provisions of this rule are comprehensive and include income from investments both under r. 3(1) and r. 3(2). Secondly, there is no reason why any distinction should have been made between investments mentioned in r. 3(1) and investments mentioned in r. 3(2).

holdings.text: the explanation applies to the computation of the profits of the chargeable accounting period July 1, 1944 to October 16, 1944

anchor.surface_text: promulgation of the Ordinance. But even if it was added subsequently, in our opinion, the explanation applies to the computation of the profits of the chargeable accounting period July 1, 1944 to October 16, 1944.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance 2002 added the Explanation; Ordinance 2004 deems it operative from the original Ordinance's commencement date via comma insertion and deeming provision; reading both harmoniously reveals retrospective legislative intent

holdings.text: the explanation ... was meant to be an explanation not only to r. 3(2) but to r. 3(1) also

anchor.surface_text: but it seems to us that if we look at the language of the explanation it was meant to be an explanation not only to r. 3(2) but to r. 3(1) also. First, the words the income from investments to be included

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation's language comprehensively covers 'income from investments ... under the provisions of this rule' including both sub-rules; no reason to distinguish investments under 3(1) and 3(2); added below 3(2) but applies to rule 3 generally

holdings.text: the answer to the question referred should be in the negative

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question referred should be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dividend income excluded under Explanation to Rule 3 as received from Binod Mills, a company carrying on business to which Ordinance applied entirely; avoids double taxation; prior contention on investments rejected by earlier Supreme Court judgment
